text: during his tenure as a US Army General
President Eisenhower developed and
utilized a method that revolutionized
our approach to tackling procrastination
in a speech delivered in 1954 he
referenced a quote by J Rosco Miller
what is important is rarely urgent and
what is urgent is rarely important by
saying this Eisenhower stressed that
effective time management required both
efficiency and Effectiveness in other
words we must spend our time on things
that are important and not just on the
tasks that are urgent to do this and to
minimize the stress of having too many
tight deadlines it's crucial to grasp
the Eisenhower Matrix Theory it works
basically by grouping tasks into four
categories based on their urgency and
their importance urgent things are ones
that are times sensitive and must be
done the soonest and important things
are the ones that have the biggest
consequences and the most writing on
them first we have the Urgent and
important category this is for the tasks
you must prioritize and complete first
next is the important but not urgent
category which you put tasks into that
you need to schedule for completion at a
later date after this is the urgent but
not important category tasks in this
group should be delegated to someone
else to complete finally we have the not
important and not urgent category any
tasks you find yourself shelving under
this group simply don't need to be
thought about and you can delete them
from your to-do list it's important to
recognize the difference between
importance and urgency when planning
your schedule by prioritizing the wrong
tasks you could be setting self back
unnecessarily in 2018 psychologists zuu
Yang and C conducted research to
investigate how people prioritize tasks
based on urgency versus importance they
found a phenomenon which they coined the
mere urgency effect basically when given
the choice between tasks that had
varying levels of reward indicating
their importance participants were more
likely to complete less important tasks
if those tasks came with a shorter time
limit this showed that the perceived
urgency of the task AKA how long they
had until it had to be completed was
prompting people to prioritize it over a
more important one with higher rewards
something that reflects badly on your
real life planning if faced with this
scenario in real life you could employ
the Eisenhower Matrix to recognize these
low reward High urgency tasks as urgent
but not important and thus make the
smart decision to delegate them to
someone else and prioritize more
important things to start using the
technique right now make a list of all
the tasks you need to complete when your
list is complete read through it and
separate the tasks into four categories
you can maybe highlight them in four
different colors arrange them in a
spreadsheet or pin them to different
columns on a corkboard starting with
your urgent and important group begin
doing those tasks immediately once those
are complete move on to important but
not urgent ones choose dates or times
and your schedule to complete these
tasks ideally in Far Enough advance of
their deadline that they don't become
too Urgent by the time you get around to
them next up is the urgent but not
important tasks the one ones you should
delegate this works best in a workplace
scenario where you can recognize tasks
that could be taken on by team members
and colleagues an example of delegating
in your personal life however could be
that you ask your friend to make a table
reservation for your dinner that week or
ask your partner to post that letter for
you the ones that you're left with are
not urgent or important and you can
scrap them from your to-do list now
being told to just do it when it comes
to your most urgent and important tasks
can be daunting especially if they
involve large projects this is where you
can use productivity techniques
alongside the Eisenhower Matrix to
really optimize your time which we will
tell you about after discussing today's
sponsor brilliant brilliant is a site
and app where you can learn math
computer science and other interesting
subjects in stem what's great about them
is that they don't teach by nearly
stating facts or formulas and making you
memorize things instead they employ an
interactive teaching style that makes
learning fun you're given intriguing
questions that test your knowledge and
fill in your gaps and misconceptions
when you come across a gap in your
knowledge they provide you with the
correct answer as well as an explanation
as to why our favorite course right now
is the how technology Works course where
you can explore topics like what
actually makes a password good or how
recommendation algorithms know what
content you'll like to try everything
brilliant has to offer for free for a
full 30 days and get 20% off an annual
plan visit brilliant.org Improvement
pill or click on the link in the
description now back to the topic at
hand our next technique is the odoro
technique and it's one of the most
powerful ones and can really help you
get through boring and high effort jobs
it was developed in the 1980s by
University student Francesco cerillo who
went on to write a 130 page book on the
method you don't need to read all that
though essentially the method involves
breaking up your working time into
manageable chunks with regular breaks
the method calls for you to cut your
work periods into 25 minutes sessions
which in this technique are called pomos
after each Pomo each 25-minute chunk you
must take a 5minute break any task you
judge that will take more than five
pomos to complete must be broken down
into smaller tasks making it more
manageable to tackle piece by piece for
example if you have an essay to write
it's likely to take you more than four
cycles of 25 minutes to complete instead
break the task down into more bite-sized
pieces task one is your introduction
task two is your first argument task
three is your counterargument and so on
use the pomero method to keep you
focused on each job at hand and you
should feel far less overwhelmed and way
more productive once you've made your
way through all parts of your task this
way you can cross the big one off the
list the advantages of this method have
been proven in various ways such as one
study in 2011 which proved that short
diversions from your tasks can help
greatly increase your focus when you go
back to working Professor Alejandra Yus
found that participants in his study
performed consistently at a higher level
with a computer task if they had too
short breaks from it during completion
he summarized his findings as showing
that deactivating and reactivating your
goals allows you to stay focused which
is exactly what you want from using the
pomero technique next time you feel
overwhelmed and unmotivated try using
these techniques by effectively
categorizing and organizing your tasks
you should be able to optimize your time
doing things and kick your
procrastination habit and by working on
your vital jobs and shorter bursts you
can keep your focus sharp and get things
done quicker have you ever tried these
techniques how do they work for you
Share down in the comments below and
make sure to stay tuned for more
self-improvement
content
